dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To making it count. Ruth, annoyed that Jack has scored a point, presses him further.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How is it you have the means to travel, Mr. Dawson?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I work my way from place to place. Tramp steamers and such. I won my ticket on Titanic here in a lucky hand at poker. (he glances at Rose) A very lucky hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All life is a game of luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A real man makes his own luck, Archie. Rose notices that Thomas Andrews, sitting next to her, is writing in his notebook, completely ignoring the conversation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Andrews, what are you doing? I see you everywhere writing in this little book. (grabs it and reads) Increase number of screws in hat hooks from 2 to 3. You build the biggest ship in the world and this preoccupies you?! Andrews smiles sheepishly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He knows every rivet in her, don't you Thomas?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All three million of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His blood and soul are in the ship. She may be mine on paper, but in the eyes of God she belongs to Thomas Andrews.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your ship is a wonder, Mr. Andrews. Truly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thankyou, Rose. We see that Andrews has come under Rose's spell. 83 TIME TRANSITION: Dessert has been served and a waiter arrives with cigars in a humidor on a wheeled cart. The men start clipping ends and lighting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (low, to Jack) Nest it'll be brandies in the Smoking Room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) Well, join me for a brandy, gentlemen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (low) Now they retreat into a cloud of smoke and congratulate each other on being masters of the universe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Joining us, Dawson? You don't want to stay out here with the women, do you? Actually he does, but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No thanks. I'm heading back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably best. It'll be all business and politics, that sort of thing. Wouldn't interest you. Good of you to come. Cal and te other gentlemen exit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jack, must you go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Time for my coach to turn back into a pumpkin. He leans over to take her hand. INSERT: We see him slip a tiny folded not into her palm. Ruth, scowling, watches him walk away across the enormous room. Rose surreptitiously opens the note below table level. It reads: "Make it count. Meet me at the clock".
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Want to go to a real party?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May I cut in, miss?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're still my best girl, Cora. Cora scampers off. Rose and Jack face each other. She is trembling as he takes her right hand in his left. His other hand slides to the small of her back. It is an electrifying moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know the steps.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just move with me. Don't think. The music starts and they are off. A little awkward at first, she starts to get into it. She grins at Jack as she starts to get the rhythm of the steops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait... stop! She bends down, pulling off her high heeled shoes, and flings them to Tommy. Then she grabs Jack and they plunge back into the fray, dancing faster as the music speeds up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How you two doin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know hwat she's say, she don't know what I say, so we get along fine. Tommy walks up with a pint for each of them. Rose chugs hers, showing off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think a first class girl can't drink? Everybody else is dancing again, and Bjorn Gundersen crashes into Tommy, who sloshes his beer over Rose's dress. She laughs, not caring. But Tommy lunges, grabbing Bjorn and wheeling him around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You stupid bastard!! Bjorn comes around, his fists coming up... and Jack leaps into the middle of it, pushing them apart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boys, boys! Did I ever tell you the one about the Swede and the Irishman goin' to the whorehouse? Tommy stands there, all piss and vinegar, chest puffed up. Then he grins and claps Bjorn on the shoulder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, you think you're big tough men? Let's see you do this. In her stocking feet she assumes a ballet stance, arms raised, and goes up on point, taking her entire weight on the tips of her toes. The guys gape at her incredible muscle control. She comes back down, then her face screws up in pain. She grabs one foot, hopping around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oooowww! I haven't done that in years. Jack catches her as she loses her balance, and everyone cracks up. THE DOOR to the well deck is open a few inches as Lovejoy watches through the gap. He sees Jack holding Rose, both of them laughing. LOVEJOY closes the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come Josephine in my flying machine And it's up she goes! Up she goes! In the air she goes. Where? There she goes! They fumble the words and break down laughing. They have reached the First Class Entrance, but don't go straight in, not wanting the evening to end. Through the doors the sound of the ship's orchestra wafts gently. Rose grabs a davit and leans back, staring at the cosmos.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't it magnificent? So grand and endless. She goes to the rail and leans on it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're such small people, Jack... my crowd. They think they're giants on the earth, but they're not even dust in God's eye. They live inside this little tiny champagne bubble... and someday the bubble's going to burst. He leans at the rail next to her, his hand just touching hers. It is the slightest contact imaginable, and all either one of them can feel is that square inch of skin where their hands are touching.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not one of them. There's been a mistake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A mistake?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh huh. You got mailed to the wrong address.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) I did, didn't I? (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing suddenly) Look! A shooting star.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was a long one. My father used to say that whenever you saw one, it was a soul going to heaven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like that. Aren't we supposed to wish on it? Jack looks at her, and finds that they are suddenly very close together. It would be so easy to move another couple of inches, to kiss her. Rose seems to be thinking the same thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What would you wish for? After a beat, Rose pulls back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something I can't have. (she smiles sadly) Goodnight, Jack. And thank you. She leaves the rail and hurries through the First Class Entrance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rose!! But the door bangs shut, and she is gone. Back to her world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had hoped you would come to me last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was tired.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Your exertions below decks were no doubt exausting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stiffening) I see you had that undertaker of a manservant follow me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will never behave like that again! Do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not some foreman in your mills than you can command! I am your fiancee-- Cal explodes, sweeping the breakfast china off the table with a crash. He moves to her in one shocking moment, glowering over her and gripping the sides of her chair, so she is trapped between his arms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes! You are! And my wife... in practice, if not yet by law. So you will honor me, as a wife is required to honor her husband! I will not be made out a fool! Is this in any way unclear? Rose shrinks into the chair. She sees Trudy, frozen, partway through the door bringing the orange juice. Cal follows Rose's glance and straightens up. He stalks past the maid, entering the stateroom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We... had a little accident. I'm sorry, Trudy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are not to see that boy again, do you understand me Rose? I forbid it! Rose has her knee at the base of her mother's back and is pulling the corset strings with both hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, stop it, Mother. You'll give yourself a nosebleed. Ruth pulls away from her, and crosses to the door, locking it. CLACK!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wheeling on her) Rose, this is not a game! Our situation is precarious. You know the money's gone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course I know it's gone. You remind me every day!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your father left us nothing but a legacy of bad debts hidden by a good name. And that name is the only card we have to play. Rose turns her around and grabs the corset strings again. Ruth sucks in her waist and Rose pulls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't understand you. It is a fine match with Hockley, and it will insure our survival.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hurt and lost) How can you put this on my shoulders? Rose turns to her, and we see what Rose sees-- the naked fear in her mother's eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you want to se me working as a seamstress? Is that what you want? Do you want to see our fine things sold at an auction, our memories scattered to the winds? My God, Rose, how can you be so selfish?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's so unfair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course it's unfair! We're women. Our choices are never easy. Rose pulls the corset tighter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, you, you're not supposed to be in here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was just here last night... don't you remember? (seeing Lovejoy coming toward him) He'll tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Hockley and Mrs. DeWitt Bukater continue to be most appreciative of your assistance. They asked me to give you this in gratitude-- He holds out two twenty dollar bills, which Jack refuses to take.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want money, I-- LOVEJOY --and also to remind you that you hold a third class ticket and your presence here is no longer appropriate. Jack spots Rose but she doesn't see him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just need to talk to Rose for a--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, please see that Mr. Dawson gets back where he belongs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir! (to Jack) Come along you. END ON ROSE, not seeing Jack hustled out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) O hear us when we cry to thee for those in peril on the sea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Reminds me of my Harvard days. T.W. McCAULEY, the gym instructor, is a bouncy little man in white flannels, eager to show off his modern equipment, like his present-day counterpart on an "Abflex" infomercial. He hits a switch and a machine with a saddle on it starts to undulate. Rose puts her hand on it, curious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The electric horse is very popular. We even have an electric camel. (to Ruth) Care to try your hand at the rowing, m'am?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be absurd. I can't think of a skill I should likely need less.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The next stop on our tour will be bridge. This way, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's a goddess amongst mortal men, there's no denyin'. But she's in another world, Jackie, forget her. She's closed the door. Jack moves furtively to the wall below the A-Deck promenade, aft.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was them, not her. (glancing around the deck) Ready... go. Tommy shakes his head resignedly and puts his hands together, crouching down. Jack steps into Tommy's hands and gets boosted up to the next deck, where he scrambles nimbly over the railing, onto the First Class deck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not bein' logical, I tell ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Amore is'a not logical.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Another ice warning, sir. This one from the "Baltic".
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thankyou, Sparks. Smith glances at the message then nonchalantly puts it in his pocket. He nods reassuringly to Rose and the group.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not to worry, it's quite normal for this time of year. In fact, we're speeding up. I've just ordered the last boilers lit. Andrews scowls slightly before motioning the group toward the door. They exit just as SECOND OFFICER CHARLES HERBERT LIGHTOLLER comes out of the chartroom, stopping next to First Officer Murdoch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did we ever find those binoculars for the lookouts?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Haven't seen them since Southampton.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Andrews, I did the sum in my head, and with the number of lifeboats times the capacity you mentioned... forgive me, but it seems that there are not enough for everyone aboard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About half, actually. Rose, you miss nothing, do you? In fact, I put in these new type davits, which can take an extra row of boats here. (he gestures along the eck) But it was thought... by some... that the deck would look too cluttered. So I was over-ruled.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slapping the side of a boat) Waste of deck space as it is, on an unsinkable ship!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sleep soundly, young Rose. I have built you a good ship, strong and true. She's all the lifeboat you need. As they are passing Boat 7, a gentlemen turns from the rail and walks up behind the group. It is Jack. He taps Rose on the arm and she turns, gasping. He motions and she cuts away from the group toward a door which Jack holds open. They duck into the--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jack, this is impossible. I can't see you. He takes her by the shoulders.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rose, you're no picnic... you're a spoiled little brat even, but under that you're a strong, pure heart, and you're the most amazingly astounding girl I've ever known and--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jack, I-- JACK No wait. Let me try to get this out. You're amazing... and I know I have nothing to offer you, Rose. I know that. But I'm involved now. You jump, I jump, remember? I can't turn away without knowin' that you're goin' to be alright. Rose feels the tears coming to her eyes. Jack is so open and real... not like anyone she has ever known.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're making this very hard. I'll be fine. Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think so. They've got you in a glass jar like some butterfly, and you're goin' to die if you don't break out. Maybe not right away, 'cause you're strong. But sooner or later the fire in you is goin' to go out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not up to you to save me, Jack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right. Only you can do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to get back, they'll miss me. Please, Jack, for both our sakes, leave me alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course the invitations had to be sent back to the printers twice. And the bridesmaids dresses! Let me tell you what an odyssey that has been... TRACKING SLOWLY IN on Rose as Ruth goes on. REVERSE, ROSE'S POV: A tabeau of MOTHER and DAUGHTER having tea. The four year old girl, wearing white gloves, daintily picking up a cookie. The mother correcting her on her posture, and the way she holds the teacup. The little girl is trying so hard to please, her expression serious. A glimpse of Rose at that age, and we see the relentless conditioning... the pain to becoming an Edwardian geisha. ON ROSE. She calmly and deliberately turns her teacup over, spilling tea all over her dress.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, look what I've done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Jack. He turns and she is standing there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I changed my mind. He smiles at her, his eyes drinking her in. Her cheeks are red with the chill wind, and her eyes sparkle. Her hair blows wildly about her face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fabrizio said you might be up--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sssshh. Come here. He puts his hands on her waist. As if he is going to kiss her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Close your eyes. She does, and he turns her to face forward, the way the ship is going. He presses her gently to the rail, standing right behind her. Then he takes her two hands and raises them until she is standing with her arms outstetched on each side. Rose is going along with him. When he lowers his hands, her arms stay up... like wings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Open them. Rose gasps. There is nothing in her field of vision but water. It's like there is no ship under them at all, just the two of them soaring. The Atlantic unrolls toward her, a hammered copper shield under a dusk sky. There is only the wind, and the hiss of the water 50 feel below.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm flying! She leans forward, arching her back. He puts his hands on her waist to steady her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing softly) Come Josephine in my flying machine... Rose cleses her eyes, feeling herself floating weightless far above the sea. She smiles dreamily, then leans back, gently pressing her back against his chest. He pushes forward slightly against her. Slowly he raises his hands, arms outstretched, and they meet hers... fingertips gently touching. Then their fingers intertwine. Moving slowly, their fingers caress through and around each other like the bodies of two lovers. Jack tips his face forward into her blowing hair, letting the scent of her wash over him, until his cheek is agianst her ear. Rose turns her head until her lips are near his. She lowers her arms, turning further, until she finds his mouth with hers. He wraps his arms around her from behind, and they kiss like this with her head turned and tilted back, surrendering to him, to the emotion, to the inevitable. They kiss, slowly and tremulously, and then with building passion. Jack and the ship seem to merge into one force of power and optimism, lifting her, buoying her forward on a magical journey, soaring onward into a night without fear. 100 IN THE CROW'S NEST, high above and behind them, lookout FREDERICK FLEET nudges his mate, REGINALD LEE, pointing down at the figures in the bow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wish I had those bleedin' binoculars. 101 JACK AND ROSE, embracing at the bow rail, DISSOLVE SLOWLY AWAY, leaving the ruined bow of the WRECK-- CUT TO: 102 INT. KELDYSH IMAGING SHACK OLD ROSE blinks, seeming to come back to the present. She sees the wreck on the screen, the sad ghost ship deep in the abyss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was the last time Titanic ever saw daylight. Brock Lovett changes the tape in the minicassette recorder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So we're up to dusk on the night of the sinking. Six hours to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you love it? There's Smith, he's standing there with the iceberg warning in his fucking hand... (remembering Rose) ... excuse me... in his hand, and he's ordering more speed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: years of experience working against him. He figures anything big enough to sink the ship they're going to see in time to turn. But the ship's too big, with too small a rudder... it can't corner worth shit. Everything he knows is wrong. ROSE is ignoring this conversation. She has the art-nouveau comb with the jade butterfly on the handle in her hands, turning it slowly. She is watching a monitor, which shows the ruins of Suite B-52/56. PUSH IN until the image fills frame.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will this light do? Don't artists need good light?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bad French accent) Zat is true, I am not used to working in such 'orreeble conditions. (seeing the paintings) Hey... Monet! He crouches next to the paintings stacked against the wall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't he great... the use of color? I saw him once... through a hole in this garden fence in Giverny. She goes into the adjoining walk-in wardrobe closet. He sees her go to the safe and start working the combination. He's fascinated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cal insist on luggin this thing everywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should I be expecting him anytime soon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not as long as the cigars and brandy hold out. CLUNK! She unlocks the safe. Glancing up, she meets his eyes in the mirror behind the safe. She opens it and removes the necklace, then holds it out to Jack who takes it nervously.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it? A sapphire?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A diamond. A very rare diamond, called the Heart of the Ocean. Jack gazes at wealth beyond his comprehension.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to draw me like your French girl. Wearing this. (she smiles at him) Wearing only this. He looks up at her, surprised, and we CUT TO: 104 ROSE'S BEDROOM. ON THE BUTTERFLY COMB as Rose draws it out of her hair. She shakes her head and her hair falls free around her shoulders. 105 IN THE SITTING ROOM Jack is laying out his pencils like surgical tools. His sketchbook is open and ready. He looks up as she comes into the room, wearing a silk kimono.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The last thing I need is another picture of me looking like a china doll. As a paying customer, I expect to get what I want. She hands him a dime and steps back, parting the kimono. The blue stone lies on her creamy breast. Her heart is pounding as she slowly lowers the robe. Jakc looks so stricken, it is almost comical. The kimono drops to the floor (this is all in cuts, lyrical).
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me when it looks right to you. She poses on the divan, settling like a cat into the position we remember from the drawing... almost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh... just bend your left leg a little and... and lower your head. Eyes to me. That's it. Jack starts to sketch. He drops his pencil and she stifles a laugh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I believe you are blushing, Mr. Big Artiste. I can't imagine Monsieur Monet blushing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sweating) He does landscapes. TIGHT ON JACK as his eyes come up to look at her over the top edge of his sketchpad. We have seen this image of him before, in her memory. It is an image she will carry the rest of her life. Despite his nervousness, he draws with sure strokes, and what emerges is the best thing he has ever done. Her pose is languid, her hands beautiful, and her eyes radiate her energy. PUSH SLOWLY IN ON ROSE'S FACE...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My heart was pounding the whole time. It was the most erotic moment of my life... up till then at least. CUT TO REVERSE: A semicircle of listeners staring in rapt, frozen silence. The story of Jack and Rose has finally and completely grabbed them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What, uh... happened next?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) You mean, did we "do it"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Sorry to disappoint you Mr. Bodine. Rose gazes at the drawing. He has X-rayed her soul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Date it, Jack. I want to always remember this night. He does: 4/14/1912. Rose meanwhile scribbles a note on a piece of Titanic stationary. We don't see what it says. She accepts the drawing from him, and crosses to the safe in the wardrobe. She puts the diamond back in the safe, placing hte drawing and the note on top of it. Closes the door with a CLUNK!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: None of the stewards have seen her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (low but forceful) This is ridiculous, Lovejoy. Find her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think I've ever seen such a flat calm, in 24 years at sea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, like a mill pond. Not a breath of wind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's make the bergs harder to see, with no breaking water at the base.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mmmmm. Well, I'm off. Maintain speed and heading, Mr. Lightoller.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And wake me, of course, if anything becomes in the slightest degree doubtful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Rose? Hello? He hears a door opening and goes through Cal's room toward hers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on! She and Jack break into a run, surprising the few ladies and gentlemen about. Rose leads him past the stairs to the bank of elevators. They run into one, shocking the hell out of the OPERATOR.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take us down. Quickly, quickly! The Operator scrambles to comply. Jack even helps him close the steel gate. Lovejoy runs up as the lift starts to descend. He slams one hand on the bars of the gate. Rose makes a very rude and unladylike gesture, and laughs as Lovejoy disappears above. The Operator gapes at her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pretty tough for a valet, this fella.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's an ex-Pinkerton. Cal's father hired him to keep Cal out of trouble... to make sure he always got back to the hotel with his wallet and watch, after some crawl through the less reputable parts of town...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kinda like we're doin' right now-- uh oh! Lovejoy has spotted them from a cross-corridor nearby. He charges toward them. Jack and Rose run around a corner into a blind alley. There is one door, marked CREW ONLY, and Jack flings it open. 115 They enter a roaring RAN ROOM, with no way out but a ladder going down. Jack latches the deadbolt on the door, and Lovejoy slams against it a moment later. Jack grins at Rose, pointing to the ladder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: After you, m'lady.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting over the din) Carry on! Don't mind us! They run through the open watertight door into BOILER ROOM SIX. Jack pulls her through the fiercely hot alley between two boilers and they wind up in the dark, out of sight of the working crew. Watching from the shadows, they see the stokers working in the hellish glow, shovelling coal into the insatiable maws of the furnaces. The whole place thunders with the roar of the fires.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're going like hell I tel you. I have fifty dollars that says we make it into New York Tuesday night! Cal looks at his gold pocket watch, and scowls, not listening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where to, Miss?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To the stars. ON JACK as her hands come out of the shadows and pull him over the seat into the back. He lands next to her, and his breath seems loud in the quiet darkness. He looks at her and she is smiling. It is the moment of truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you nervous?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Au contraire, mon cher. He strokes her face, cherishing her. She kisses his artist's fingers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put your hands on me Jack. He kisses her, and she slides down in the seat under his welcome weight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at this one, he wants his private train to meet him. La dee da. (slaps them down) We'll be up all bloody night on this lot. Phillips start to receive an incoming message from a nearby ship, the Leyland frieghter CALIFORNIAN, which jams his outgoing signal. At such close range, the beeps are deafening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Christ! It's that idiot on the Californian. Cursing, Phillips furiously keys a rebuke.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stupid bastard. I try to warn him about the ice, and he says "Keep out. Shut up. I'm working Cape Race."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now what's he sending?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "No seasickness. Poker business good. Al". Well that's it for me. I'm shutting down. As Evans wearily switches off his generator, Groves goes out on deck. PAN oFF Him to reveal the ship is stopped fifty yards from the edge of a field of pack ice and icebergs stretching as far as the eye can see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're trembling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's okay. I'm alright. He lays his cheek against her chest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can feel your heart beating. She hugs his head to her chest, and just holds on for dear life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Well, I wasn't the first teenage girl to get seduced in the backseat of a car, and certainly not the last, by several million. He had such fine hands, artists' hands, but strong too... roughened by work. I remember their touch even now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can smell ice, you know, when it's near.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bollocks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well I can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a better idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got yer! REVERSE: the back seat is empty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When this ship docks, I'm getting off with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. It doesn't make any sense. That's why I trust it. Jack pulls her to him and kisses her fiercely. 130 IN THE CROW'S NEST Fleet nudges Lee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cor... look at that, would ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're a bloody sight warmer than we are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well if that's what it takes for us two to get warm, I'd rather not, if it's all the same. They both have a good laugh at that one. It is Fleet whose expression falls first. Glancing forward again, he does a double take. The color drains out of his face. FLEET'S POV: a massive iceberg right in their path, 500 yards out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bugger me!! Fleet reaches past Lee and rings the lookout bell three times, then grabs the telephone, calling the bridge. He waits precious seconds for it to be picket up, never taking his eyes off the black mass ahead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pick up, ya bastard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Is someone there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. What do you see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Iceberg right ahead!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thankyou. (hangs up, calls to Murdoch) Iceberg right ahead! Murdoch sees it and rushes to the engine room telegraph. While signaling "FULL SPEED ASTERN" he yells to Quartermaster Hitchins, who is at the wheel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hard a' starboard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (standing behind Hitchins) Hard'a starboard. The helm is hard over, sir. CRASH SEQUENCE / SERIES OF CUTS: 132 CHIEF ENGINEER BELL is just checking the soup he has warming on a steam manifold when the engine telegraph clangs, then goes... incredibly... to FULL SPEED ASTERN. He and the other ENGINEERS just stare at it a second, unbelieving. Then Bell reacts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Full astern! FULL ASTERN!! The engineers and greasers like madmen to close steam valves and start braking the mighty propeller shafts, big as Sequias, to a stop. 133 IN BOILER ROOM SIX, Leading Stoker FREDERICK BARRETT is standing with 2nd Engineer JAMES HESKETH when the red warning light and "STOP" indicator come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut all dampers! Shut 'em!! 134 FROM THE BRIDGE Murdoch watches the burg growing... straight ahead. The bow finally starts to come left (since the ship turns the reverse of the helm setting). MURDOCH'S jaw clenches as the bow turns with agonizing slowness. He holds his breath as the horrible physics play out. 135 IN THE CROW'S NEST Frederick Fleet braces himself. 136 THE BOW OF THE SHIP thunders right at CAMERA and-- KRUUUNCH!! The ship hits the berg on its starboard bow. 137 UNDERWATER we see the ice smashing in the steel hull plates. The iceberg bumps and scrapes along the side of the ship. Rivets pop as the steel plate of the hull flexes under the load. 138 IN #2 HOLD the two stewards stagger as the hull buckles in four feet with a sound like THUNDER. Like a sledgehammer beating along outside the ship, the berg splits the hull plates and the sea pour in, sweeping them off their feert. The icy water swirls around the Renault as the men scramble for the stairs. 139 ON G-DECK forward Fabrizio is tossed in his bunk by the impact. He hears a sound like the greatly amplified squeal of a skate on ice. 140 IN BOILER ROOM SIX Barret and Hesketh stagger as they hear the ROLLING THUNDER of the collision. They see the starboard side of the ship buckle in toward them and are almost swept off their feet by a rush of water coming in about two feet above the floor. 141 ON THE FORWARD WELL DECK Jack and Rose break their kiss and look up in astonishment as the berg sails past, blocking out the sky like a mountain. Fragments break off it and crash down onto the deck, and they have to jump back to avoid flying chunks of ice. 142 ON THE BRIDGE Murdoch rings the watertight door alarm. He quicky throws the switch that closes them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hard a 'port! Judging the berg to be amidships, he is trying to clear the stern. 143 BARRETT AND HESKETH hear the DOOR ALARM and scramble through the swirling water to the watertight door between Boiler Rooms 6 and 5. The room is full of water vapor as the cold sea strikes the red hot furnaces. Barrett yells to the stokers scrambling through the door as it comes down like a slow guillotine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: IN THE FIRST CLASS SMOKING ROOM

dialogue.raw_text: Go Lads! Go! Go! He dives through into Boiler Room 5 just before the door rumbles down with a CLANG. 144 JACK AND ROSE rush to the starboard rail in time to see the berg moving aft down the side of the ship. 145 In his stateroom, surrounded by piles of plans while making notes in his ever-present book, Andrews looks up at the sound of a cut-crystal light fixture tinkling like a windchime. He feels the shudder run through the ship. And we see it in his face. Too much of his soul is in this great ship for him not to feel its mortal wound. 146 IN THE FIRST CLASS SMOKING ROOM Gracie watches his highball vibrating on the table. 147 IN THE PALM COURT, with its high arched windows, Molly Brown holds up her drink to a passing waiter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, can I get some ice here, please? Silently, a moving wall of ice fills the window behind her. She doesn't see it. It disappears astern. 148 OMITTED 149 IN THE CROW'S NEST Fleet turns to his Lee...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oy, mate... that was a close shave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Smell ice, can you? Bleedin' Christ!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stiffly, to Moody) Note the time. Enter it in the log. Captain Smith rushes out of his cabin onto the bridge, tucking in his shirt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was that, Mr. Murdoch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An iceberg, sir. I put her hard a' starboard and run the engines full astern, but it was too close. I tried to port around it, but she hi... and I--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Close the emergency doors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The doors are closed. Together they rush out onto the starboard wing, and Murdoch points. Smith looks into the darkness aft, then wheels around to FOURTH OFFICER BOHALL.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Find the Carpenter and get him to sound the ship.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ma-- che cazzo! 152 IN HIS STATEROOM Tommy gets out of his top bunk in the dark and drops down to the floor. SPLASH!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cor!! What in hell--?! He naps on the light. The floor is covered with 3 inches of freezing water, and more coming in. He pulls the door open, and steps out into the corridor, which is flooded. Fabrizio is running toward him, yelling something in Italian. Tommy and Fabrizio start pounding on doors, getting everybody up and out. The alarm spreads in several languages.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why have the engines stopped? I felt a shudder?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 I shouldn't worry, m'am. We've likely thrown a propeller blade, that's the shudder you felt. May I bring you anything? THOMAS ANDREWS brushes past them, walking fast and carrying an armload of rolled up ship's plans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks okay. I don't see anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could it have damaged the ship?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It didn't seem like much of a bump. I'm sure we're okay. Behind them a couple of steerage guys are kicking the ice around the deck, laughing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If this is the direction the rats were runnin', it's good enough for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no cause for alarm. Please, go back to your rooms. He is stopped in his tracks by Cal and Lovejoy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, sir. There's no emergency--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes there is, I have been robbed. Now get the Master at Arms. Now you moron!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A five degree list in less than ten minutes. SHIP'S CARPENTER JOHN HUTCHINSON enters behind him, out of breath and clearly unnerved.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's making water fast... in the forepeak tank and the forward holds, in boiler room six. ISMAY enters, his movements quick with anger and frustration. Smith glances at him with annoyance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why have we stopped?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've struck ice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, do you think the ship is seriously damaged?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glaring) Excuse me. Smith pushes past him, with Andrews and Hutchinson in tow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it, lads. Get the hell up! They scramble up the escape ladders.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess it's nothing too serious. I'm going back to my cabin to read. A 20ish YALE MAN pops through the door wearing a topcoat over pajamas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say, did I miss the fun? Rose and Jack come up the steps from the well deck, which are right next to the three men. They stare as the couple climbs over the locked gate. A moment later Captain Smith rounds the corner, followed by Andrews and Carpenter Hutchinson. They have come down from the bridge by the outside stairs. The three men, their faces grim, crush right past Jack and Rose. Andrews barely glances at her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you shore up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not unless the pumps get ahead. The inspection party goes down the stairs to the well deck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (low, to her) It's bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have to tell Mother and Cal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now it's worse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come with me, Jack. I jump, you jump... Right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Jack follows Rose through the door inside the ship.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've been looking for you miss. Lovejoy follows and, unseen, moves close behind Jack and smoothly slips the diamond necklace into the pocket of his overcoat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something serious has happened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. Two things dear to me have disappeared this evening. Now that one is back... (he looks from Rose to Jack) ... I have a pretty good idea where to fine the other. (to Master at Arms) Search him. The Master at Arms steps up to Jack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Coat off, mate. Lovejoy pulls at Jack's coat and Jack shakes his head in dismay, shrugging out of it. The Master at Arms pats him down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is horseshit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cal, you can't be serious! We're in the middle of an emergency and you-- Steward Barnes pulls the Heart of the Ocean out of the pocket of Jack's coat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this it? Rose is stunned. Needless to say, so is Jack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right then. Now don't make a fuss. He starts to handcuff Jack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you believe it, Rose. Don't!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncertain) He couldn't have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course he could. Easy enough for a professional. He memorized the combination when you opend the safe. FLASHBACK: Rose at the safe, looking in the mirror and meeting Jack's eyes as he stands behind her, watching.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I was with him the whole time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (just to her, low and cold) Maybe he did it while you were putting your clothes back on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They put it in my pocket!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (holding Jack's coat) It's not even your pocket, son. (reading) "Property of A. L. Ryerson". Lovejoy shows the coat to the Master at Arms. There is a label inside the collar with the owner's name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was reported stolen today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was going to return it! Rose-- Rose feels utterly betrayed, hurt and confused. She shrinks away from him. He starts shouting to her as Lovejoy and the Master at Arms drag him out into the hall. She can't look him in the eye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rose, don't listen to them... I didn't do this! You know I didn't! You know it! She is devastated. Her mother lays a comforting hand on her shoulder as te tears well up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do women believe men?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When can we get underway, do you think? Smith glares at him and turns his attention to Andrews' drawing. The builder points to it for emphasis as he talks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Water 14 feet above the keel in ten minutes... in the forepeak... in all three holds... and in boiler room six.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Five compartments. She can stay afloat with the first four compartments breached. But not five. Not five. As she goes down by the head the water will spill over the tops of the bulkheads... at E Deck... from one to the next... back and back. There's no stopping it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The pumps--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The pumps buy you time... but minutes only. From this moment, no matter what we do, Titanic will founder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But this ship can't sink!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She is made of iron, sir. I assure you, she can. And she will. It is a mathematical certainty. Smith looks like he has been gutpunched.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An hour, two at most. Ismay reels as his dream turns into his worst nightmare.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And how many aboard, Mr. Murdoch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two thousand two hundred souls aboard, sir. A long beat. Smith turns to his employer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I believe you may get your headlines, Mr. Ismay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turn to the right! Pull the falls taut before you unchock. Have you never had a boat drill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No sir! Not with these new davits, sir. He looks around, disguisted as the crew fumble with the davits, and the tackle for the "falls"... the ropes which are used to lower the boats. A few passengers are coming out on deck, hesitantly in the noise and bitter cold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had better go dress. Ruth exits and Hockley crosses to Rose. He regards her coldly for a moment, then SLAPS her across the face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is a little slut, isn't it? To Rose the blow is inconsequential compared to the blow her heart has been given. Cal grabs her shoulders roughly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at me, you little-- There is a loud knock on the door and an urgent voice. The door opens and their steward puts his head in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, I've been told to ask you to please put on your lifebelt, and come up to the boat deck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get out. We're busy. The steward persists, coming in to get the lifebelts down from the top of a dresser.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry about the inconvenience, Mr. Hockley, but it's Captain's orders. Please dress warmly, it's quite cold tonight. (he hands a lifebelt to Rose) Not to worry, miss, I'm sure it's just a precaution.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is ridiculous. In the corridor outside the stewards are being so polite and obsequious they are conveying no sense of danger whatsoever. However, it's another story in...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Everybody up. Let's go. Put your lifebelts on. IN THE CORRIDOR outside, another steward is going from door to door along the hall, pouncing and yelling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Lifebelts on. Lifebelts on. Everybody up, come on. Lifebelts on... People come out of the doors behind the steward, perplexed. In the foreground a SYRIAN WOMAN asks her husband what was said. He shrugs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. The distress call. CQD. Tell whoever responds that we are going down by the head and need immediate assistance. Smith hurries out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Blimey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you ought to try that new distress call... S.O.S. (grinning) It may be our only chance to use it. Phillips laughs in spite of himself and starts sending history's first S.O.S. Dit dit dit, da da da, dit dit dit... over and over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are all the passengers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They've all gone back inside. Too damn cold and noisy for them. Andrews feels like he is in a bad dream. He looks at his pocketwatch and heads for the foyer entrance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's doing, sonny? You've got us all trussed up and now we're cooling our heels. The young steward backs away, actually stumbling on the stairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, mum. Let me go and find out. The jumpy piano rhythm of "Alexander's Ragtime Band" comes out of the first class lounge a few yards away. Band leader WALLACE HARTLEY has assembled some of his men on Captain's orders, to allay panic. Hockley's entourage comes up to the A-deck foyer. Cal is carrying the lifebelts, almost as an afterthought. Rose is like a sleepwalker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just the God damned English doing everything by the book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no need for language, Mr. Hockley. (to Trudy) Go back and turn the heater on in my room, so it won't be too cold when we get back. Thomas Andrews enters, looking around the magnificent room, which he knows is doomed. Rose, standing nearby, sees his heartbroken expression. She walks over to him and Cal goes after her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw the iceberg, Mr. Andrews. And I see it in your eyes. Please tell me the truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The ship will sink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're certain?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. In an hour or so... all this... will be at the bottom of the Atlantic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My God. Now it is Cal's turn to look stunned. The Titanic? Sinking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please tell only who you must, I don't want to be responsible for a panic. And get to a boat quickly. Don't wait. You remember what I told you about the boats?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I understand. Thankyou. Andrews goes off, moving among the passengers and urging them to put on their lifebelts and get to the boats.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're wanted by the Purser, sir. Urgently.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on. I'll keep an eye on him. Lovejoy pulls a pearl handled Colt .45 automatic from under his coat. The Master at Arms nods and tosses the handcuff key to Lovejoy, then exits with the crewman. Lovejoy flips the key in the air. Catches it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Carpathia says they're making 17 knots, full steam for them, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And she's the only one who's responding?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The only one close, sir. She says they can be here in four hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four hours! The enormity of it hits Smith like a sledgehammer blow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Bride. He turns as Bride exits, and looks out onto the blackness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) My God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hadn't we better get the women and children into the boats, sir? Smith just nods, a bit abstractly. The fire has gone out of him. Lightoller sees the awesome truth in Smith's face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the men) Right! Start the loading. Women and children! The appalling din of escaping steam abruptly cuts off, leaving a sudden unearthly silence in which Lightoller's voice echoes. ON WALLACE HARTLEY raising his violin to play.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Number 26. Ready and-- The band has reassembled just outside the First Class Entrance, port side, near where Lightoller is calling for the boats to be loaded. They strike up a waltz, lively and elegant. The music wafts all over the ship.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ladies, please. Step into the boat. Finally one soman steps across the gap, into the boat, terrified of the drop to the water far below.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You watch. They'll put us off in these silly little boats to freeze, and we'll all be back on board by breakfast. Cal, Rose and Ruth come out of the doors near the band.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My brooch, I left my brooch. I must have it! She turns back to go to her room but Cal takes her by the arm, refusing to let her go. The firmness of his hold surprises her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay here, Ruth. Ruth sees his expression, and knows fear for the first time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 (to Steward #3) I told the stupid sods no luggage. Aw, bloody hell! He throws up his hand at the sight of a family, loaded down with cases and bags, completely blocking the corridor. Fabrizio and Tommy push past the stewards, going the other way. They rech a huge crowd gathered at the bottom of the MAIN 3RD CLASS STAIRWELL. Fabrizio spots Helga with the rest of the Dahl family, standing patiently with suitcases in hand. He reaches her and she grins, hugging him. Tommy pushes to where he can see what's holding up the group. There is a steel gate across the top of the stairs, with several stewards and seamen on the other side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay calm, please. It's not time to go up to the boats yet. Near Tommy, an IRISHWOMAN stands stoically with two small children and their battered luggage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are we doing, mummy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're just waiting, dear. When they fiish putting First Class people in the boats, they'll be startin' with us, and we'll want to be all ready, won't we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lower away! By the left and right together, stady lads! The boat lurches as the falls start to pay out through the pulley blocks. The women gasp. The boat descends, swaying and jerking, toward the water 60 feet below. The passengers are terrified.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know... I believe this ship may sink. (crosses to Jack) I've been asked to give you this small token of our appreciation... He punches Jack hard in the stomach, knocking the wind out of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Compliments of Mr. Caledon Hockley. Lovejoy flips the handcuff key in the air, catches it and puts it in his pocket. He exits. Jack is left gasping, handcuffed to the pipe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is no time to waste! (yelling and waving his arms) Lower away! Lower away! Lower away! FIFTH OFFICER LOWE, a baby-faced 28, and the youngest officer, looks up from the tangled falls at the madman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get out of the way, you fool!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know who I am? Lowe, not having a clue nor caring, squares up to Ismay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a passenger. And I'm a ship's bloody officer. Now do what you're told! (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning away) Steady men! Stand by the falls!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (numbly, backing away) Yes, quite right. Sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Women and children only! Sorry sir, no men yet. Another rocket bursts overhead, lighting the crowd. Startled faces turn upward. Fear now in the eyes. DANIEL MARVIN has his Biograph camera set up, cranking away... hoping to get an exposure off the rocket's light. he has Mary posed in front of the scene at the boats.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're afraid, darling. Scared to death. That's it! Either she suddenly learned to act or she is petrified. ROSE watches the farewells taking pace right in front of her as they step closer to the boat. Husbands saying goodbye to wives and children. Lovers and friends parted. Nearby MOLLY is getting a reluctant woman to board the boat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, you heard the man. Get in the boat, sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will the lifeboats be seated according to class? I hope they're not too crowded--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Mother shut up! (Ruth freezes, mouth open) Don't you understand? The water is freezing and there aren't enough boats... not enough by half. Half the people on this ship are going to die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not the better half. PUSH IN ON ROSE'S FACE as it hits her like a thunderbolt. Jack is third class. He doesn't stand a chance. Another rocket bursts overhead, bathing her face in white light.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You unimaginable bastard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Ruth, get in the boat. These are the first class seats right up here. That's it. Molly practically hands her over to Lightoller, then looks around for some other women who might need a push.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Rose. You're next, darlin'. Rose steps back, shaking her head.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rose, get in the boat!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, mother. Ruth, standing in the tippy lifeboat, can do nothing. Cal grabs Rose's arm but she pulls free and walks away through the crowd. Cal catches up to Rose and grabs her again, roughly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going? To him? Is that it? To be a whore to that gutter rat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd rather be his whore than your wife. He clenches his jaw and squeezes her arm viciously, pulling her back toward the lifeboat. Rose pulls out a hairpin and jabs him with it. he lets go with a curse and she runs into the crowd.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lower away!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rose! ROSE!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stuff a sock in it, would ya, Ruth. She'll be along. The boat lurches downward as the falls are paid out. TRACKING WITH ROSE, as she runs through the clusters of people. She looks back and a furious Cal is coming after her. She runs breathlessly up to two proper looking men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That man tried to take advantage of me in the crowd! Appalled, they turn to see Cal running toward them. Rose runs on as the two men grab Cal, restraining him. She runs throught the First Class entrance. Cal breaks free and runs after her. He reaches the entrance, but runs into a knot of people coming out. He pushes rudely through them...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep pulling... away from the ship. Pull.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ain't you boys ever rowed before? Here, gimme those oars. I'll show ya how it's done. She climbs over Ruth to get at the oars, stepping on her feet. Around them the evacuation is in full swing, with boats in the water, others being lowered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit. He tries to pull one hand out of the cuffs, working until the skin is raw... no good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help!! Somebody!! Can anybody hear me?! (to himself) This could be bad. 181 THE CORRIDOR outside is deserted. Flooded a couple of inches deep. Jack's voice comes faintly through the door, but there is no one to hear it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyone in here? Rose runs up to him, breathless.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Andrews, thank God! Where would the Master at Arms take someone under arrest?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? You have to get to a boat right away!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! I'll do this with or without your help, sir. But without will take longer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Take the elevator to the very bottom, go left, down the crewman's passage, then make a right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bottom, left, right. I have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hurry, Rose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, miss, lifts are closed-- Without thinking she grabs him and shoves him back into the lift.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm through with being polite, goddamnit!! I may never be polite the rest of my life! Now take me down!! The operator fumbles to close the gate and start the lift.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on girls, join in, it'll keep ya warm. Let's go Ruth. Grab an oar! Ruth just stares at the spectacle of the great liner, its rows of lights blazing, slanting down into the sullen black mirror of the Atlanic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Left, crew passage. She spots it and slogs down the flooded corridor. The place is understandably deserted. She is on her own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right, right... right. She turns into a cross-corridor, splashing down the hall. A row of doors on each side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jack? Jaaacckk??
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: !! In here! 187 IN THE HALL Rose hears his voice behind her. She spins and runs back, locating the right door, then pushes it open, creating a small wave. She splashes over Jack and puts her arms around him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jack, Jack, Jack... I'm sorry, I'm so sorry. They are so happy to see each other it's embarrassing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That guy Lovejoy put it in my pocket.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See if you can find a key for these. Try those drawers. It's a little brass one. She kisses his face and hugs him again, then starts to go through the desk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So... how did you find out I didn't do it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't. (she looks at him) I just realized I already knew. They share a look, then she goes back to ransacking the room, searching drawers and cupboards. Jack sees movement out the porthole and looks out. A LIFEBOAT hits the surface of the water, seen from below.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I despise small boats. I just know I'm going to be seasick. I always get seasick in small boats. Good Heavens, there's a man down there. In a lit porthole beneath the surface she sees Jack looking up at her... a face in a bubble of light under the water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no key in here. They look around at the water, now almost two feet deep. Jack has pulled his feet up onto the bench.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have to go for help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) I'll be right back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll wait here. She runs out, looking back at him once from the doorway, then splashes away. Jack looks down at the swirling water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello? Somebody?! She turns a corner and runs along another corridor in a daze. The hall slopes down into water which, shimmers, reflecting the light. The margin of the water creeps toward her. A YOUNG MAN appears, running through the water, sending up geysers of spray. He pelts past her without slowing, his eyes crazed...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help me! We need help! He doesn't look back. It is like a bad dream. The hull gongs with terrifying sounds. The lights flicker and go out, leaving utter darkness. A beat. Then they come back on. She finds herself hyperventilating. That one moment of blackness was the most terrifying of her life. A STEWARD runs around the nearest corner, his arms full of lifebelts. He is upset to see someone still in his section. He grabs her forcefully by the arm, pulling her with him like a wayward child.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, then, let's get you topside, miss, that's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait. Wait! I need your help! There's--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No need for panic, miss. Come along!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, let me go! You're going the wrong way! He's not listening. And he won't let her go. She SHOUTS in his ear, and when he turns, she punches him squarely in the nose. Shocked, he lets her go and staggers back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To Hell with you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See you there, buster! The steward runs off, holding his bloody nose. She spits after him. Just the way Jack taugh: her. She turns around, SEES: a glass case with a fire-axe in it. She breaks the glass with a battered suitcase which is lying discarded nearby, and seizes the axe, running back the way she came. 192 AT THE STAIRWELL she looks down and gasps. The water has flooded the bottom five steps. She goes down and has to crouch to look along the corridor to the room where Jack is trapped. Rose plunges into the water, which is up to her waist... and powers forward, holding the axe above her head in two hands. She grimaces at the pain from the literally freezing water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will this work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll find out. They are both terrified, but trying to keep panic at bay. He positions the chain connecting the two cuffs, stretching it taut across the steel pipe. The chain is of course very short, and his exposed wrists are on either side of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Try a couple practice swings. Rose hefts the axe and thunks it into a wooden cabinet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now try to hit the same mark again. She swings hard and the blade thunks in four inches from the mark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, that's enough practice. He winces, bracing himself as she raises the axe. She has to hit a target about an inch wide with all the foce she can muster, with his hands on either side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sounding calm) You can do it, Rose. Hit it as hard as you can, I trust you. Jack closes his eyes. So does she. The axe comes down. K-WHANG! Rose gingerly opens her eyes looks... Jack is grinning with two separate cuffs. Rose drops the axe, all the strength going out of her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice work, there, Paul Bunyan. He climbs down into the water next to her. He can't breathe for a second.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit! Excuse my French. Ow ow ow, that is cold! Come on, let's go. They wade out into the hall. Rose starts toward the stiars going up, but Jack stops her. There is only about a foot of the stairwell opening visible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too deep. We gotta find another way out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now there's somethin' you don't see every day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here you! You'll have to pay for that, you know. That's White Star Line property--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning together) Shutup! Jack leads her past the dumbfounded steward. They join the steerage stragglers going aft. In places the corridor is almost completely blocked by large families carrying all their luggage. AN IRISH WOMAN gives Rose a blanket, more for modesty than because she is blue-lipped and shivering.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, lass, cover yerself. Jack rubs her arms and tries to warm her up as they walk along. The woman's husband offers them a flask of whiskey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This'll take the chill off. Rose takes a mighty belt and hands it to Jack. He grins and follows suit. Jack tries a number of DOORS and IRON GATES along the way, finding them all locked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you hold the boat a moment? I have to run back to my room for something-- Lightoller grabs her and shoves her bodily into the boat. Thomas Andrews rushes up to him just then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are the boats being launched half full?! Lightoller steps past him, helping a seaman clear a snarled fall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not now, Mr. Andrews.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing down at the water) There, look... twenty or so in a boat built for sixty five. And I saw one boat with only twelve. Twelve!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... we were not sure of the weight--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rubbish! They were tested in Belfast with the weight of 70 men. Now fill these boats, Mr. Lightoller. For God's sake, man! The shot HANDS OFF to Cal, who sees Lovejoy hurrying toward him through the aisle connecting the port and starboard sides of the boat deck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's not on the starboard side either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're running out of time. And this strutting martinet... (indicating Lightoller) ...isn't letting any men in at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The one on the other side is letting men in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then that's our play. But we're still going to need some insurance. (he starts off forward) Come on. Cal charges off, heading forward, followed by Lovejoy. The SHOT HANDS OFF to a finely dressed elderly couple, IDA and ISADOR STRAUSS.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Ida, get into the boat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. We've been together for forty years, and where (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: you go, I go. Don't argue with me, Isador, you know it does no good. He looks at her with sadness and great love. They embrace gently.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lower away!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fabrizio! Fabri! Fabrizio turns and sees Jack and Rose pushing through the crowd. He and Jack hug like brothers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The boats are all going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We gotta get up there or we're gonna be gargling saltwater. Where's Tommy? Fabrizio points over the heads of the solidly packed crowd to the stairwell. Tommy has his hands on the bars of the steel gate which blocks the head of the stairwell. The crew open the gate a foot or so and a few women are squeezing through.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Women only. No men. No men!! But some terrified men, not understanding English, try to rush through the gap, forcing the gate open. The crewmen and stewards push them back, shoving and punching them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Get back! Get back you lot! (to the crewmen) Lock it!! They struggle to get the gate closed again, while Steward #2 brandishes a small revolver. Another holds a fire axe. They lock the gate, and a cry goes up among the crowd, who surge forward, pounding against the steel and shouting in several languages.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For the love of God, man, there are children down here! Let us up, so we can have a chance! But the crewmen are scared now. They have let the situation get out of hand, and now they have a mob. Tommy gives up and pushes his way back through the crowd, going down the stairs. He rejoins Jack, Rose and Fabrizio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's hopeless that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, whatever we're goin' to do, we better do it fast. Fabrizio turns to Helga, praying he can make himself understood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a lot of hand gestures) Everyone... all of you... come with me now. We go to the boats. We go to the boats. Capito? Come now! They can't understand what he's saying. They can see his urgency, but OLUF DAHL, the patriarch of the family, shakes his head. He will not panic, and will not let his family go with this boy. Fabrizio turns to Helga.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Helga... per favore... please... come with me, I am lucky. Is my destiny to go to America. She kisses him, then steps back to be with her family. Jack lays a hand on his shoulder, his eyes saying "Let's go".
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will never forget you. He turns to Jack, who leads the way out of the crowd. Looking back Fabrizio sees her face disappear into the crowd.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (holding up stacks of bills) I make my own luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting the .45 in his waistband) So do I. Cal grins, putting the money in his pocket as they go out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go to the main stairwell, with everyone else. It'll all get sorted out there. Jack takes one look at this scene and finally just loses it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God damn it to Hell son of a bitch!! He grabs one end of a bench bolted to the floor on the landing. He starts pulling on it, and Tommy and Fabrizio pitch in until the bolts shear and it breaks free. Rose figures out what they are doing and clears a path up the stairs between the waiting people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Move aside! Quickly, move aside! Jack and Tommy run up the steps with the bench and RAM IT INTO THE GATE with all their strength. It rips loose from its track and falls outward, narrowly mssing the steward. Led by Jack, the crowd surges though. Rose steps up to the cowering steward and says in her most imperious tone:
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you have any intention of keeping your pathetic job (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: with the White Star Line, I suggest you escort these good people to the boat deck... now. Class wins out. He nods dumbly motions form them to follow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come back! Come back to the ship! CHIEF OFFICER WILDE joins him, blowing his silver whistle. 208 FROM BOAT 6 the whistle comes shrilly across the water. Quartermaster Hitchins grips the rudder in fear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The suction will pull us right down if we don't keep going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got room for lots more. I say we go back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! It's our lives now, not theirs. And I'm in charge of this boat! Now row!! 209 CAPTAIN SMITH, at the rail of the boat deck, lowers his megaphone slowly
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The fools.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ben, what's the occasion?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have dressed in our best and are prepared to go down like gentlemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's admirable, Ben. (walking on) I'll sure and tell your wife... when I get to New York.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It seems we've been dealt a bad hand this time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get back! Keep order! The men back down. Fifth Officer Lowe standing in the boat, yells to the crew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lower away left and right! Lightoller turns away from the crowd and, out of their sight, breaks his pistol open. Letting out a long breath, he starts to LOAD IT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're too late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are still some boats forward. Stay with this one... Murdoch. He seems to be quite... practical. 215 IN THE WATER BELOW there is another panic. Boat 13, already in the water but still attached to its falls, is pushed aft by the discharge water being pumped out of the ship. It winds up directly under boat 15, which is coming downt he right on top of it. The passengers shout in panic to the crew above to stop lowering. They are ignored. Some men put their hands up, trying futilely to keep the 5 tons of boat 15 from crushing them. Fred Barrett, the stoker, gets out his knife and leaps to the after falls, climbing rudely over people. He cuts the aft falls while another crewman cuts the forward lines. 13 drifts out from beneath 15 just seconds before it touches the water with a slap. Cal, looking down from the rail hears GUNSHOTS-- CUT TO: 216 EXT. BOAT DECK / A-DECK, PORT, AFT Fifth Officer Lowe, in Boat 14 is firing his gun as a warning to a bunch of men threatening to jump into the boat as it passes the open promenade on A-Deck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay back you lot! BLAM! BLAM!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's starting to fall apart. We don't have much time. Cal sees three dogs run by, including the black French bulldog. Someone has released the pets from the kennels. Cal sees Murdoch turn from the davits of boat 15 and start walking toward the bow. He catches up and falls in beside him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Murdoch, I'm a businessman, as you know, and I have a business proposition for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The boats are gone! She sees Colonel Gracie chugging forward along the deck, escorting two first class ladies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Colonel! Are there any boats left?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (staring at her bedraggled state) Yes, miss... there are still a couple of boats all the way forward. This way, I'll lead you! Jack grabs her hand and they sprint past Gracie, with Tommy and Fabrizio close behind. ANGLE ON THE BAND... incredibly they are still playing. Jack, Rose and the others run by.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Music to drown by. Now I know I'm in First Class.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So we have an understanding then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding curtly) As you've said. Cal, satisfied, steps back. He finds himself waiting next to J. Bruce Ismay. Ismay does not meet his eyes, nor anyone's. Lovejoy come sup to Cal at that moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've found her. She's just over on the port side. With him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Women and children? Any more women and children? (glancing at Cal) Any one else, then? Cal looks longingly at his boat... his moment has arrived.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God damn it to hell! Come on. He and Lovejoy head for the port side, taking a short-cut through the bridge. Bruce Ismay, seeing his oppurtunity, steps quickly into Collapsible C. He stares straight ahead, not meeting Murdoch's eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue
